generative AI models are all based on a type of machine learning model called a neural net this was originally proposed

from the 1940s onwards if you've ever heard the term AI winter or AI summer it's referring to sort of these boom and
bus periods um across the 20th century in this area but it really kind of started to pick up speed in the 1980s

bigger you can make neural Nets the more sophisticated or accurate their predictions can become but this requires
the use of processing units that are really efficient at doing huge amounts of matrix

allowed us to transform gpus into allpurpose matrix multiplication machines and therefore made the training
of really large neural Nets much more feasible however as you increase the
size of models they also have increasing demands for data therefore the next big
advancement was the release of large open data sets such as image net for computer vision and common craw for

more like intensive and large models so following these developments
the first of these two fields to really take off was computer vision with the development of a specific type of neural
net called convolutional neural networks or snn not to be confused with the news network the way cnns are constructed
allows them to take raw images as an input and determine for themselves which
features are actually interesting so say they might be able to see ears of an animal or the branches of a tree when I
say c i shouldn't say it these are not anthropomorphic models but they can determine these features for themselves
and they can use it for tasks like image classification telling images apart
prior to that what researchers had to do was to hand annotate those features
themselves so you can see this really freed up researchers to start feeding bigger and bigger data sets into these
models because it required a lot less pre-processing
oops sorry however CNN's are not really that good at generating images and they
were superseded for this purpose by another type of neural net called generative adversarial networks or Gans
so Gans are imageo image models what they do is they take in a huge data set of images and they try to learn patterns
in that data set and they apply these patterns to try to generate novel images that might belong to that data set
so as you can see from the timeline Gams were a very very successful type of
image generation algorithm and most image generation models up until 2020 were ganss one of the most well-known
examples you might remember it was a website called this person does not exist there's a sample from that um
website I love this website when it came out really blew my mind but basically what they did is they used a model
called style Gan and they import a whole bunch of portraits and then the model was able to use that information to
generate people who had never existed jumping back over to natural language processing the first big
breakthrough actually came back in 2007 with the development of a type of model
and type of neural net called long shirt short-term memory networks very catchy name or lstms which is what everyone
calls them because saying long short-term memory networks as you can see is quite difficult so lstms were a
big breakthrough because they were the first of these neural Nets to really understand words in their context and
that meant that unsurprisingly they were a lot better um than previous models at being able to do a range of natural
language tasks such as text uh classification text summarization and
machine translation in fact you might have noted that Google translate suddenly got a lot better in 2016 it's
because they started using lstms under the hood however a major Lim limitation of
lstms is that they're forced to process a piece of text sequentially so say you
have a sentence they start with the first word they extract some information about that they keep it in a shter
memory they then move on to the second word extract more information add that to the memory and so on so as you can
probably imagine this caused a number of technical problems but the biggest of
these is that it was really difficult to scale these models and this was overcome by a type of neuronet called Transformer
models these avoid sequential processing of uh sentences basically they're able
to process a whole bunch of words at the same time and this meant that models
could start getting really really huge a really cool thing about Transformer
networks is as they start like getting trained over huge amounts of text Data
they actually start encoding a bunch of information from that um data including
things like how that Lang language functions rules of grammar things like that so this has kicked off the current
generation of text processing models and this is where we can have the large in large language models the branch of
Transformer models that turned into generative models are generative pre-trained Transformers or gpts and the
first of these came out in 2018 so gpts have been such a successful
type of generative text model that pretty much every single one of the many many many gpts that have come out over
the last 3 years have been based on this architecture that includes some Heavy Hitters that you've definitely heard of
like chat gbt GPT 4 Falcon and llama other way
around so the development of the transform architecture actually allowed us to also move into a new uh era of
image generation which is text to image models so the basis of these models is another type of neural net called click
and this is a Transformer based model which is trained with images in order to
create a model that can find the closest text description for a given image clip was released at the same time as Dal it
uses a Transformer model to map text to images and then rank based on the
description that is closest to a given image however new way of using clip was
quickly discovered and this was of course diffusion model models these models are Guided by clip to
sequentially denoise an image um which contains random pixels into something that gets closer and closer to a text
input and as you can see this has ended up being one of the most successful type of text to image models with pretty much
every single one of these models coming out now based on this architecture okay history lesson over
now that we have an understanding of where these models came from let's have a closer look at the GPT models so we're
not going to look at all of them we'd be here for hours but let's have a look at those that were trained by open AI which
was actually the company that first developed the GPT models so a really interesting problem
as I've said several times for natural language processing is machine translation and this was the first
application of Transformer models so in order to do machine translation a Transformer model needs two components
an encoder and a decoder the job of the encoder is to learn
everything it can about the source language so some sort of source language like English and then be able to take in
Source inputs the thing that you want to translate it then needs to pass what it's learned about that input over to
the decoda the job of the decoda is a bit more complicated it needs to learn
everything it can about the target language it then needs to take the information that was passed over by the
encoder and word by word try to predict the closest matching sequence in the
target language so let's have a look at an example of this let's say we have this sequence in English I visited Italy
and we don't want to translate it to German so the enoda will have learned as much as it can about English and the
theoda will have learned as much as it can about German and then what the encoder will do is take in that input
pass it over to the decoda and the decoda will word by word find the closest matching sequence in
German however something the researchers quickly realized is that these Dakota units all on their own were pretty
interesting as we discussed the Dakota's whole job is to learn everything it can about a target language and use that
knowledge to predict the next word in a sequence based on an input researcher
started to think well what if we cut out the encoder unit and we cut out this Source language and we just train a
decoda unit on the same language so what we can do is we can show a decoda unit
millions and millions of sentences and over time what we'll get is a model that has basically learned based on a given
input the most likely word to come next and so what you end up with you know you
can see from this example is a model that if you put in an input like I have
it can take you know uh you can predict the next most likely next word and the most likely next word after
that and the most likely next word after that and so on so you might be wondering
in this example why it's not always picking the top most likely word this is a mechanism
called temperature to kind of oversimplify it a bit basically what it does is it takes the top most likely
words and it picks one of them rather than always picking the most likely word so temperature was introduced in order
to make large language models sound a bit more natural but it also does have some side effects such as making these
models a little bit more likely to make up things or hallucinate we're going to come back to hallucinations at the end
of this talk so interestingly these Dakota based models were not really initially
interesting because of their potential to generate text but because it solved a really important problem remember when I
was talking about cnns and I was saying that they were really interesting because they suddenly allowed researchers to scale up the amount of
data that they could UT into the models well gpts did the same thing with text
based models you know machine learning often has this constraint that you do need to manually prepared data in some
way it might be pairing up things it might be adding labels or might be hand annotating features and what GPT models
allow you to do is have this readymade data set where you can just cut sentences in half at one point and have
a model that's basically just trying to predict the next word in the sentence this scales really easily
so this was the basis of the GPT models and in conjunction with that scalable Transformer architecture is the secret
of how these models have been able to get so big these models roughly work by stacking the amount of decoda units they
have and this increases the size of the models which will'll often hear described by the number of parameters
and roughly you can say the more parameters that a model has the more powerful it is the more sophisticated
its predictions are so the first GPT was 120 million
parameters the second was 13 times that size at 1.5 billion parameters and
they've just kept growing and growing up to the current GPT 4 which is estimated to be 1 trillion parameters although

the successive generations to get better and better at doing a range of natural language tasks and interestingly aart
from the first one gpt1 they were not explicitly trained to do this but they
can be taught how to do this through very carefully giving them instructions
what's now currently known as prompt engineering what we used to call metal learning back in you know the days when

they are to give biased or toxic outputs or to hallucinate so in an attempt to mitigate

such as this one about writing a high coup about sausages and then a group of people were
recruited in order to write sort of Exemplar answers for these
prompts and this was repeated for a whole range of prompts ac across a whole
scope of different tasks so you end up with a whole data set containing these Exemplar answers to given
prompts so you might be thinking wait the problem that you said uh GPT solved
is that it helped us get these really large data sets we didn't need to manually create data anymore so if we're
manually creating data to make chat GPT how is it bigger than gpt3
well the trick is a process called fine-tuning fine-tuning is where you
take a data set that's been trained on General data and you use a smaller data set that's focused on a particular task
or domain and you use that to refine the outputs this General um model will give
you so in the case of say co-pilot that was originally based on a model called
codex which is a fine-tuning of gpt3 using Code samples and in the case of chat GPT we have a fine-tune version of
GPT 3.5 with 355 billion parameters and it's been basically fine-tuned to give
us more truthful less biased outputs but the real secret to chat GPT
success comes in The Next Step so we have our fine chune version of GPT
3.5 and what they then did is they took one prompt and they fed it into the model four times they then took a second
group of people and they got them to rate each of these outputs taking into account how truthful how high quality
how unbiased each of the outputs were and the higher the score obviously the better the
answer they then used these ratings to train a second model so the model takes
the output of the GPT model and it tries to predict the score that a particular
uh Rader would give it and then all of these components are glued together to give us ch G PT so you
feed a prom into chat GPT the fine-tune GPT 3.5 or 4 model in chat GPT 4 takes
in that and it gives you an output that output is then fed into the rer model
which then tries to predict which score the Raiders would give it and then that is fed back into the GPT model which is
then kind of slowly changed over time to be more in line with good ratings and
less in line with bad ratings and this is a process called reinforcement learning from Human feedback you may
have heard this term and the idea is that over time these models will kind of move to create less biased more truthful
outputs so if you ever wondered what that little thumbs up and down is next to your chat gbt output it's basically
helping to refine these models so having covered the context

foro well from the start it gives us the wrong answer it tells us that we need to

system the problem with this thinking is that it confuses the output of an AI system
with the mechanism that took to get there in humans we can do these skill-based assessments of intelligence
because this is how it works in humans a human demonstrating impressive performance or learning something
difficult quickly is indicative of a raw underlying ability in AI or let's call them what
they are machine learning models it doesn't work that way if they can take shortcuts to get to their training goal
they absolutely will the mistake is thinking that the development of an
intelligence is a requirement for them to get to that goal it absolutely is not
and this is such a common effect it has a name it's called the kaggle effect those of you who have messed around in
machine learning you will know kaggle kaggle is a very famous website which hosts machine learning competitions so
people will compete to get the best model performance on some sort of task
classification regression whatever and the solutions that tend to win tend to
be so good at solving that problem they almost seem to demonstrate
intelligence but as soon as you try to get them to do something that's a bit outside of what they were trained on
they fail they show brittleness what we're looking for in intelligence system instead is the
ability of that system to generalize to be able to solve problems that it hasn't necessarily seen before and in order to
make this a bit easier to work with let's break it down into a hierarchy of generalization we start with no
generalization this includes systems which know all of the possible outcomes in advance such as a program using
configurations of tic-tac-toe in order to be able to play that game the second is local generalization
this is where a model can make inferences on things that it hasn't seen before but if they're twoo different to
what it was trained on it cannot the kaggle effect broad generalization reflects the
ability to act independently or complete some broad activity domain so a famous
example of this is Steve wnc's coffee cup test wnc of Apple Fame he posits
that if you have a system that can go into a kitchen and complete all of the steps to make a cup of coffee without
assistance it's demonstrating some sort of broad generalization and fully automatic self-driving cars are also
part of this level then we have extreme generalization this is essentially human
level intelligence what you have is a system that can solve problems that maybe only Shar some vague commonalities
with things that it's seen before and it can do that across a scope of tasks that would be relevant to
humans so at this stage you might be thinking you're spending a lot of time talking about human like abilities we're

the top level universality and this includes the capability of an artificial system to
complete tasks that really have no relevance to
humans universality however should be dismissed as at least an initial goal
for a couple of reasons first I'm assuming most of you are developers and you know for a problem to be useful it

general ability to learn called G or general intelligence we use our general
intelligence to be able to complete broad or develop broad abilities such as being able to drive or cook and within
each broad ability we have tasks that we can complete such as being able to whisk eggs or use an
indicator and what you can see is that this definition of intelligence in humans actually lines up quite nicely
with our hierarchy of generalization and artificial systems we can line up extreme generalization with general
intelligence broad generalization with broad cognitive abilities and local generalization or even no generalization
with task specific skills so given that the measurement of intelligence in humans is quite an

let's have a look at how we might do this fris Chalet is a very well-known
researcher in AI he works at Google if any of you have messed around with machine learning at all you might know
the Caris package he wrote that he proposed a method of measuring intelligence in artificial systems so he
defines it as following an artificial system should demonstrate the ability to complete a task using a skill program
which was developed in order to create that to solve that task which was in
turn created by a humanlike intelligence system and I hope again you can see that
these line up with G general intelligence broad abilities and task specific skills in humans so of course
there are some feedback mechanisms within this system skill programs get better over time as they are exposed
exposed to trying to solve particular tasks within their domain and the
intelligent like human system itself can also learn as it's exposed to more and more
tasks Chalet also argues that if we're talking about a humanlike intelligence
system we should give it the ability to have the priors that humans are born
with so humans are kind of a supposed by developmental psychologist to be born
with the ability to do elementary geometry in physics arithmetic and understand that others have
agency skill programs of course can evolve as they are exposed to more and
more tasks that are within their domain and tasks themselves can differ based on their generalization difficulty
this is basically how much the system has to generalize in order to solve that
problem in other words how different it is from things that it's been directly exposed to before so putting this all
together we can actually come up with a formula for measuring intelligence and artificial systems and Chalet says that
it could work like something like the following so for one specific task being
solved by an artificial system in one specific way we can Define how difficult
it's going to be for that system to solve it as the generalization difficulty divided by how close it is to
the system priors and things that the system has had experience with before so let me break that down a bit basically
what we're saying is that when an artificial system comes across a task that it wants to solve in a particular
way it's going to be a lot harder for the system to solve it if it hasn't really seen something like that before
and it's going to be easier if it has seen something like that before now of course there are generally
multiple ways of solving a problem so what we can do is we can say the difficulty of a system of solving a
particular task is given is average across all the ways of approaching that
task for that system shal also says that we should add a subjective component how
valuable or impressive it is that that system can solve that task so you know it's a lot more impressive to have a

numbers so this is just for one task what we then need to do is Define a
scope of tasks that would be relevant to what we want this system to be ble to do if we wanted to be humanlike we need to
take a sampling of tasks that are relevant to humans so what we can then do is average it the ability of the

does is it gives us a measurement of the skill acquisition efficiency of that system across a range of relevant tasks

general int intelligence Chalet went one step further and he proposed a potential

100 problems which have the following format basically there are three

this Rule and then apply it to a final example and you can see this one is

you'll know that these systems work by kind of like root forcing patterns just
